21. Midline catheter tip position and catheter-related complications in
antimicrobial therapy: A multi-center randomized controlled trial
(Zhao L et al. Int J Nurs Stud. 2023)

results.statement:
Study protocol. Evaluation indicators and judgment criteria were
incidence of catheter-related complications and
indwelling catheter duration.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 10

results.statement: Study findings. Longest dwell time recorded was of 131 days.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: Key points. MC tips placed in the subclavian or axillary vein of the chest wall had the lowest complication rates.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 6

results.statement:
Study conclusions. Placing midline catheter tips in the subclavian or axillary vein significantly reduces catheter-
related complications during antimicrobial therapy.

22. Comparing incidence of thrombosis in PICC and midlines and evaluating
the role of anticoagulation, site of insertion, and risk factors
(Zohourian H et al. J Assoc Vasc Access. 2019)
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 22

results.statement:
Study protocol. Inclusion criteria: Adult patients who underwent
either a PICC or midline catheter placement
between January 1 and December 31, 2016.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 2

results.statement:
Study protocol. The means or frequencies of potential catheter-
related thrombosis (CT) risk factors were compared
between cases and controls.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 6

results.statement: Study findings. The insertion site, whether basilic, brachial, or cephalic vein, did not significantly affect the risk of thrombosis.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 2

results.statement: Study findings. Prophylactic anticoagulation showed reduced CT trend but was not statistically significant.

Study findings. Patients were spared an average of 12 vascular access attempts, during their hospitalization, when

Study objective. To guide clinicians in selecting the most

results.statement: Study findings. Midlines are appropriate for medium-term therapy (typically up to 4 weeks).
